# Blockchain as a Service (BaaS): What You Need to Know!

  * Report this article 

Rajai M. Nuseibeh

###  Rajai M. Nuseibeh

####  Managing Director | Venture Builder | Digital Transformer

Published Mar 26, 2023

\+ Follow

The rise of blockchain technology has opened up new possibilities for
businesses to build decentralized products and dApps. However, building a
blockchain from scratch can be a daunting and expensive task, requiring a high
level of technical expertise. Blockchain as a Service (BaaS) has emerged as a
viable solution, offering companies a ready-to-use infrastructure to create
digital products using blockchain fundamentals. In this article, we will
explore the technical aspects of BaaS, cost, security, scalability, and
approach using a BaaS solution versus building a blockchain from scratch.

### What is BaaS?

The need for Blockchain as a Service (BaaS) emerged as a result of the growing
interest in blockchain technology and its potential for various applications.
However, building and deploying blockchain applications requires significant
expertise in distributed systems, cryptography, and software development,
which can be a significant challenge for many businesses and organizations.

BaaS is a cloud-based service that allows users to create and manage digital
products using blockchain technology. Instead of building a blockchain from
scratch, businesses can use a pre-built infrastructure that is scalable,
secure, and cost-effective. BaaS providers offer a range of tools and
applications that simplify the process of building decentralized products,
such as smart contracts, transaction management, and user authentication.

### Why BaaS?

BaaS emerged as a way to make it easier for businesses and developers to build
and deploy blockchain-based applications without having to invest in building
their own blockchain infrastructure. With BaaS, users can leverage pre-built
blockchain networks and infrastructure provided by cloud service providers,
which allows them to focus on building the application logic and functionality
rather than worrying about the underlying blockchain infrastructure.

In addition, BaaS makes it easier for businesses to experiment with blockchain
technology without having to commit significant resources to building and
maintaining their own infrastructure. This is particularly beneficial for
smaller businesses and startups who may not have the resources to build and
maintain their own blockchain infrastructure.

### BaaS Use Cases

BaaS can be used in a wide range of industries, including finance, healthcare,
and supply chain management.

### BaaS vs. Building your BlockChain from Scratch

When deciding whether to use a BaaS solution or build a blockchain from
scratch, there are several factors to consider. One of the key advantages of
BaaS is that it allows organizations to focus on their core competencies
without having to worry about the underlying blockchain infrastructure. This
can lead to faster time-to-market and lower development costs. Additionally,
BaaS providers often offer a range of pre-built components and templates that
can be used to accelerate the development process.

One key consideration is cost. Building a blockchain from scratch can be
expensive, requiring significant investment in hardware, software, and
personnel. BaaS solutions, on the other hand, offer a more cost-effective
option, with pay-as-you-go pricing models and no upfront costs.

Another consideration is security. Building a blockchain from scratch can
provide greater security and control, but also requires a higher level of
technical expertise to ensure that the system is secure. BaaS providers offer
pre-built security protocols and compliance standards to ensure that the
infrastructure is secure.

Scalability is another important factor to consider. BaaS providers offer a
scalable infrastructure that can grow as your business grows, while building a
blockchain from scratch can be limited in its scalability and require
significant resources to maintain.

Governance is also an important consideration when using BaaS. Organizations
need to ensure that they have the necessary control and oversight over their
blockchain applications. This includes issues such as data ownership, privacy,
and compliance.

When building a decentralized application, organizations have the option of
using an existing blockchain protocol such as Ethereum or building their own
blockchain infrastructure. Using an existing blockchain protocol such as
Ethereum offers several advantages, including a large and growing developer
community, a well-established ecosystem of tools and services, and high levels
of security and scalability.

However, using an existing blockchain protocol also has its limitations. For
example, organizations may be limited by the functionality provided by the
protocol, and they may be subject to the protocol’s governance and consensus
mechanisms.

### Cost Structure

Some common ways that BaaS providers monetize their services:

  1. Subscription Model: Some BaaS providers charge a monthly or annual subscription fee for access to their blockchain infrastructure and APIs. The subscription fee may vary depending on the level of usage, such as the number of requests made to the blockchain network or the amount of data stored.
  2. Pay-Per-Use Model: Some BaaS providers charge based on usage, such as the number of API requests or the amount of data transferred. In this model, customers only pay for the resources they use.
  3. Gas Fees: Some BaaS providers may pass on the Ethereum gas fees to their customers. Gas fees are the fees paid to the Ethereum network for executing smart contracts or transactions. When a user interacts with a dApp deployed on the Ethereum network using a BaaS provider, they may be charged a gas fee to cover the cost of executing the smart contract or transaction.
  4. Custom Pricing: Some BaaS providers may offer custom pricing based on the specific needs of the customer. For example, if a customer requires a high level of performance or custom integrations, the provider may charge a higher fee.

The pricing model for a BaaS service can vary, and it is important to review
the pricing and usage terms of a BaaS provider to understand the cost of using
their service. Depending on the provider and the specific offering, customers
may be charged a monthly subscription fee, a pay-per-use fee, gas fees, or
custom pricing based on their needs.

### Some useful BaaS Links

  1. Microsoft Azure — https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/services/blockchain-service/ Azure Blockchain Service provides fully managed, high-availability blockchain networks with built-in governance and compliance for consortiums.
  2. Amazon Web Services (AWS) — https://aws.amazon.com/managed-blockchain/ Amazon Managed Blockchain makes it easy to create and manage scalable blockchain networks using open-source frameworks like Hyperledger Fabric and Ethereum.
  3. IBM Blockchain — https://www.ibm.com/blockchain/platform IBM Blockchain Platform provides a cloud-based blockchain platform for building, operating, and scaling blockchain networks across multiple environments.
  4. Oracle Blockchain Platform — https://www.oracle.com/cloud/blockchain-platform.html Oracle’s blockchain platform provides a pre-assembled, pre-configured blockchain infrastructure that can be deployed in a cloud environment in just a few clicks.
  5. Alibaba Cloud BaaS — https://www.alibabacloud.com/blockchain-as-a-service Alibaba Cloud provides a comprehensive blockchain platform for developers and enterprises, including blockchain middleware, smart contract management, and consortium management tools.
  6. Baidu Blockchain-as-a-Service — https://cloud.baidu.com/product/baas.html Baidu offers a comprehensive blockchain-as-a-service platform for developing and deploying blockchain-based applications, including smart contract development, deployment, and management tools.

### Conclusion

BaaS offers businesses a cost-effective, secure, and scalable solution for
building decentralized products and dApps. Choosing the right BaaS provider is
critical to the success of a blockchain project and can have a significant
impact on its scalability, speed, and cost-effectiveness. Whether you choose
to use a BaaS solution like Infura or build your own blockchain using a
development framework like Hardhat, it’s important to consider factors such as
security, scalability, and cost when making your decision. As the blockchain
industry continues to evolve, BaaS will play an increasingly important role in
helping businesses to realize the full potential of this transformative
technology.
